newsitem.title: BOSNIA: Serb leader signs away nationalist war aims.
newsitem.headline: Serb leader signs away nationalist war aims.

text.p: The Serb member of Bosnia's new collective presidency has signed an oath of loyalty to the state he and fellow hardline nationalists vowed never to recognise.

Momcilo Krajisnik reluctantly bowed to international pressure on Tuesday evening and put his signature to the "solemn declaration", pledging to support Bosnian statehood and the U.S.-brokered peace agreement.
After signing the oath, Krajisnik shook hands with his former foes, the Moslem chairman of the presidency, Alija Izetbegovic, and Croat member Kresimir Zubak.
It was a moment without fanfare or ceremony, but for many Sarajevans it symbolised the end of the Bosnian conflict that raged from 1992 to 1995.
Krajisnik was a powerful figure in the Serb leadership which sought to carve out a separate state in Bosnia and divide the capital Sarajevo into two cities, one Serb and one Moslem.
The Serbs, backed by the Yugoslav army, held the upper hand militarily throughout much of the war, tightening their stranglehold on Sarajevo and other towns when it suited them.

But Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic, widely blamed for helping to incite the conflict, later forced his Serb proteges to swallow a peace accord after the tide turned against the flagging Serb war machine.
The Serb hardliners were made to accept a treaty that preserves Bosnia as a loose union comprised of a Serb republic and a Moslem-Croat federation.
Krajisnik had to sign the declaration in Sarajevo's battered national museum, which was repeatedly fired on by Serb gunners laying siege to the city during the war.
Wearing an elegant blue suit, Krajisnik smiled after putting his name to a statement that effectively renounced Serb war aims.
"If this small sacrifice is a contribution to the peace then I will be happy," Krajisnik said afterward.
He said he was optimistic the common institutions governing post-war Bosnia would succeed.
The joint bodies would function "if we respect each other, if we develop a system of trust, and if we manage to establish equality," Krajisnik said.
Analysts said the signing merely confirmed what had already become clear, that the Bosnian Serbs have no choice but to abide by the terms of the Dayton peace accord.
Diplomats have warned the Serbs they will miss out on badly needed reconstruction aid if they persist in obstructing common institutions.
They said Serb officials have already begun quietly cooperating with plans to set up a single central bank in Bosnia for Serb and Moslem-Croat territories.
"The Bosnian Serb republic cannot survive alone. If it tries, it would slide into the middle ages," said one Western diplomat.
Krajisnik had refused to sign the oath three weeks ago and boycotted an inauguration ceremony, forcing Western diplomats to wait for hours as his chair stood empty on the stage.
Izetbegovic and Zubak signed the same "solemn declaration" at the earlier ceremony.
Serb deputies to the newly-elected Bosnian parliament were also expected to sign the oath soon, Western mediators said.
Diplomats, including U.S. President Bill Clinton's envoy, John Kornblum, applauded the signing on Tuesday and said it was a boost for the peace process.
The signing took place after a session of the three-man presidency which met for the second time since post-war general elections were held on September 14.

The presidency has been plagued by a dispute over where the body should meet. The presidency members agreed a compromise on Tuesday in which the body would convene alternately in the city centre and the Serb-held suburb of Lukavica.
Kornblum and European envoys also managed to defuse, or at least delay, an impasse over local elections.
International organisers announced the municipal polls set for November would be postponed until next year to allow time to work out innumerable political and logistical difficulties.
